"End-of-project evaluation of the UNDP parliamentary project in Georgia and recommendations"

description.narrative: Establishing Parliament as a credible institution with greater role in policymaking and EU integration by: (a) improving effectiveness of Parliament; (b) strengthening policymaking and oversight functions; (c) enhancing its role in EU integration
independent political entity
Elections - elections

1. Availability of Parliament's Institutional Reform Plan (IRP). 2. New mandate for the Parliament's international relations services. 3. Citizen-oriented public outreach activities. Number of Parliament's commitments in Open Government Partnership (OGP). 4. Number of amendments to parliamentary Rules of Procedure (RoP), including alignment with the latest constitutional changes. 5. Terms of Reference for donor coordination system in place and operational. 6. Number of committee action plans in place and operational. 7. Number of staff trainings on legislative and financial monitoring functions (summoning committee meetings, conducting government hearings, organizing public sessions, scrutinizing program budgets, utilizing budget execution and State Audit reports, etc.) 8. Action plan and communications roadmap of Committee on European integration in place and operational. Number of staff trainings on legal harmonization and overall integration issues; knowledge-sharing activities (study visits, conferences) with EU Member States. 9. Number of public outreach activities (Europe Day celebration, media workshops, etc.) on European integration processes.

comment.narrative: 1. The Parliament of Georgia lacks a vision of its development strategy. 2. Insufficient structured approach to international relations. Respective parliamentary services perform only protocol functions. 3. The Parliament's public trust is not sufficient. It lacks transparency and adequate public outreach. 4. Parliamentary Rules of Procedure (RoP) are not realigned with the latest constitutional amendments. 5. Donor coordination in the Parliament remains ineffective. 6. Parliamentary committees lack strategic approach to exercising their constitutional functions. 7. Law-making and oversight capacities of parliamentary committees remain weak. 8. There is a cross-party consensus in favour of Georgia's accelerated European integration; however, both Members and staff of the Parliament lack sufficient knowledge of European issues. 9. There is a low public awareness on Georgia-European Union relations, where the Parliament has a decisive role to play.

1. Institutional Reform Plan finalized and adopted by the Parliament. 2. Concept on International relations agreed with the Parliament; respective amendments to the parliamentary regulations made. 3. Communications strategy developed. Open Parliament Georgia Action Plan developed. 4. Amendments to Parliamentary Rules of Procedure (RoP) initiated 5. Newly introduced donor coordination mechanism operational. 6. All 4 strategic action plans of the committees are operational. 7. Parliamentary staff , including from targeted sector committees have greater capacities for fulfilling their duties 8. Action plan of the Committee on European Integration (CEI), communications roadmap and capacity development plan finalized. .

1. Institutional Reform Plan was finalized and is currently under discussion by the Bureau of the Parliament. The Plan focuses on the current needs and challenges of the Parliament and identifies strategic goals in the direction of lawmaking, government oversight, communications, human resource and financial management. 2. Concept on international relations was approved by the Parliament. Respective amendments to the regulations of the Parliament's International Relations Department were prepared and are pending signature by the Speaker of the Parliament. When approved, the Department will expand its tasks to include parliamentary diplomacy as on of major directions and provide respective services to the MPs. 3. Parliament's communications action plan was developed and is operational. Open Parliament Georgia Action plan was developed and adopted by the Parliament Bureau in July 2015. The Plan contains 18 commitments to further parliamentary openness, transparency, citizen engagement and promote new technologies and innovation. As a result of exemplary cooperation between the Parliament and civils society during the elaboration of the action plan, the Parliament was awarded OGP Government Champions Award during OGP Global Summit in Mexico, in October 2015. 4. Revision of Parliamentary Rules of Procedure is suspended until the next phase of the Project (due to fund shortage) and will resume from late 2016, i.e. after parliamentary elections. 5. New donor coordination mechanism has been developed but has not been initiated yet due to unavailability of the Speaker and his Cabinet. 6. All 4 strategic action plans of the committees are operational. As verified under the assessment report by the independent consultant (Kevin Deveaux), the committees have considerably improved their performance as a result of action plans: their work has become more structured, cooperation improved with different stakeholders, staff capacities have increased. 7. Comprehensive capacity de

1. Institutional Reform Plan adopted and operational. 2. Amendments to the regulations of the Parliament's International Relations Department adopted. Staff trained to perform new duties under the updated regulations. 3. Communications Department staff trained to better implement communications action plan. Action plan for next years updated. 4. At least 50% of Open Parliament Georgia Action Plan commitments implemented. 5. Newly introduced donor coordination mechanism operational. 6. Induction program for newly-elected MPs designed in close cooperation with the Parliament. Respective departments trained to ensure local ownership and sustainability of the process. First phase of induction program conducted. Induction materials prepared and published. 7. Parliament assisted in launching its first program-based budgets. International consultancy provided.

1. Institutional Reform Plan was adopted on 11 May 2016 by the Bureau of the Parliament. It has served as a basis to launch functional analysis in the Parliament which is an on-going process now. 2. Amendments to the Charter of the Parliament's International Relations Department were approved and signed by the Speaker of Parliament in September 2016. The Department plans to recruit new staff members who will be delivered with intensive capacity building trainings in the Project's II Phase (starting from 2017). 3. Communications Department staff has been trained on a number of issues. Next steps for the communications action plan have been developed. 4. Around 60%% of Open Parliament Georgia Action Plan commitments have been implemented. 5. Donor coordination mechanism has not been operational yet. The work will continue in the Project's II Phase, i.e. with the new parliamentary leadership. 6. Induction program for newly-elected MPs has been designed in close cooperation with the Parliament. Respective departments have been trained to ensure local ownership and sustainability of the process. Induction materials were prepared and published. All three phases of the induction program have been successfully implemented in 2016 and January 20017. 7. International consultancy has been provided to the Parliament in launching its first program-based budgets. Consultancy is still ongoing within the Project's II Phase where three parliamentary structural units (healthcare committee, legal committee and international relations department) will pilot their PBBs in 2017.

description.narrative: Establishing Parliament as a credible institution with greater role in policymaking and EU integration by: (a) improving effectiveness of Parliament; (b) strengthening policymaking and oversight functions; (c) enhancing its role in EU integration
independent political entity
Elections - elections

Number of implemented IRP goals; Number of implemented OPG commitments; Evaluations by MPs of the work of IRD and PR Departments; MP induction system; Number of committee action plans and annual reports; Quality of committee conclusions on draft budget and budget execution reports; Quality of Parliament scrutiny of draft legislation, including for harmonized laws; Quality of explanatory notes accompanying the draft legislation; Integrated cross-committee action plan regarding AA/DCFTA; Number of citizens aware and supporting Georgias EU integration agenda.

comment.narrative: Despite achieved progress in parliamentary strengthening in recent years, the Georgian Parliament requires continued support, as there remain a number of areas that need to be addressed. In general terms, the Parliament is yet insufficiently strong vis--vis the Government, particularly visible through a low number of legislative initiatives by Members of Parliament and weak government oversight. Limited knowledge and skills of the Parliament staff result in insufficient services to the MPs. Consequently, technical expertise is frequently unavailable for MPs to scrutinize legislation and initiate draft laws. Budgetary and financial scrutiny by sector committees requires further strengthening. Although Parliament succeeded in developing a number of strategic documents, like IRP and OPG AP, both need to be followed up and operationalized. The Parliament is also faced with the challenge of increasing its role in the European integration process through adequate involvement in the legal harmonization exercise and effective government scrutiny of the AA/DCFTA implementation. MPs and staff lack sufficient knowledge of European issues, which also results in low public awareness on Georgia-EU relations.

M&E framework is developed to monitor the implementation of the Parliament's IRP. At least 50% of OPG AP 2015-2016 commitments are implemented; Special guide on OGP practice for parliamentarians is published; IRD and PR Departments capacities are raised through at least 4 different trainings and workshops; Concept for MP induction program is developed and respective parliamentary departments trained to deliver induction trainings; informational materials for induction trainings are published; Parliament's respective staff is advised on PBB, development of pilot PBBs are launched; Committee Staff Manual is finalized; Needs assessment on parliament's role in EU integration is conducted.

M&E framework to monitor the implementation of the Parliament's IRP has not been developed yet as the Parliament will be updated IRP considering the new realities and challenges as well as the new vision of the newly-elected Parliament. Around 60% of OPG AP 2015-2016 commitments have been implemented; Special guide on OGP practice for parliamentarians has been developed; IRD and PR Departments capacities have been raised through 2 trainings for IRD and 2 trainings and one study visit for PR Department. Concept for MP induction program has been developed and respective parliamentary departments trained to deliver induction trainings; informational materials for induction trainings have been published and distributed to MPs; all three phases of the induction program have been conducted in 2016 and January 2017. Parliament's respective staff has been advised on PBB by the Project's Slovenian consultant and on-job-consultancy is on-going to pilot PBBs in healthcare and legal committees and IRD. Committee Staff Manual has been finalized and after its official presentation in the Parliament (envisaged in April 2017), staff trainings will kick off. Needs assessment on parliament's role in EU integration has been conducted and a baseline study report developed on the role of the Parliament in the implementation of EU-Georgia Association Agreement.

Progress of the implementation of the Institutional Reform Plan (IRP) is assessed and recommendations provided. Amendments to Parliamentary Rules of Procedure (RoP) are initiated. 40% of Open Parliament Georgia Action Plan (2017-2018) is implemented. PBBs are piloted in the select committees and departments. Study visit to Austrian Parliament is organized. Capacity development support to IRD is provided. Parliaments Human Resource Strategy is developed. Strategies and multi-year action plans of beneficiary committees are developed and presented. Work is in progress to support the committees in preparing their annual committee reports. Meetings of committees with different stakeholders is facilitated. Committees are further trained on financial oversight skills. Committee Staff Manual is published and presented. Parliaments action plan on engagement/implementation of EU-Georgia AA is developed and presented. International parliamentary conference dedicated to EU integration issues is organized.

Assessment of the implementation progress of the IRP has moved to 2018 as in 2017 the Parliament was mostly focused on the constitutional reform and is currently undertaking the reform of its Rules of Procedure that will have a great impact on the progress of implementation of IRP goals. The Project has been facilitating the work of the Parliament's working group on the Rules of Procedure and providing high-level international advisory services. With the Parliament's request the Project has engaged in the implementation of another important reform in the Parliament which aims at revising and restructuring the role, mandate and functions of the Parliament's research and analytical services. New induction program for the first-time parliamentarians (over 60 MPs) was implemented. Program-based budgets were piloted in two parliamentary committees and one department; however, due to the parliamentary elections in Austria, the study visit was postponed to early 2018. The Project continued facilitating the work of the Parliament's Permanent Council on Open and Transparent Governance and as a result, a new legislative openness action plan (2017) has been developed and adopted by the Parliament Bureau in May 2017. A number of openness commitments were implemented with the Project support, including adapting Parliaments web-site for Persons with Disabilities (PwDs), developing an accessibility plan of Tbilisi Parliament building for PwDs, providing possibilities of citizen comments to draft legislation on the website. Parliament's mobile application and open data portal are under construction. Amendments to the RoP on e-petitions, e-signatures and providing feedback on citizen comments on draft legislation are finalized and expected to be initiated by the Parliament in the coming months. Following the Project's recommendations on the revision of the mandate/charter of the Parliament's International Relations Department, the new unit on interparliamentary diplomacy was forme

description.narrative: Improved funding ratio of optimal needs of PAs measured by financial sustainability score card

comment.narrative:
047
The baseline level was 034 excluding the assumed increase in funding from revenues generated by the sister project see below

0625
The ratio of current financing to optimally required financing reached 058 at yearend 2013 according to Financial Scorecard at midterm review This figure takes the total revenues available to PAs and divides it by the optimal funding calculation at 2013 Following MTR the PEB agreed to adjust this target downwards from the original 07 for two reasons First the optimal funding foreseen in the Financial Scorecard increased compared to project outset which made it even more challenging to achieve the planned financing level A more fundamental reason to reduce the target however was that all assumed incremental funding sources are falling somewhat short of their planned additions to system revenues as described below The Project Documents Annex G assumed an improvement of 1114 million from the tourism and concession revenues generated as a result of the sister project 2013 revenues from tourism and concessions amounted to almost 650000 While not all tourism and concession revenues are actually attributable to the sister project for purposes of these calculations they are all attributed to the sister project Nevertheless it seems unlikely that tourism revenues will increase by the planned amount by 2017 An improvement of 1019 million was assumed from State funding So far while there has been a GEL increase in the budget no dollar increase has been achieved the GEL exchange rate weakened from 14GEL in 2008 to 168GEL in 2013 The 2008 baseline was 29 million in State funding for the PAsthe same amount as is shown in 2013 Finally CNFs own target at present is to reach 800000 per annum by 2017 an increase of 300000 from 2013 but still 150000 short of the planned 950000 annual contribution assumed from CNF in the project document If CNF funding can reach 800000 and tourism revenues or the state budget can increase by 200000 the revised 0625 target can be achieved

A quantitative assessment of the funding ratio will be completed for the TE in 2017

description.narrative: Governance Reform Fund (GRF) project serves the overall objective of further strengthening capacities of the Government of Georgia and increasing its effectiveness and efficiency.

Support the development of an efficient public administration system with a stronger capacity of the government to implement a national development agenda that will strengthen the rule of law and improve conditions for democratic accountability
independent political entity

comment.narrative: Georgia has made considerable progress in making its public administration system more effective, efficient, transparent, and citizen-friendly. International partners and donors have supported the Government of Georgia in these efforts. However, challenges persist in the consistent implementation of evidence-based decision making, policy formulation, long-term strategy development, as well as the retention of institutional capacity. In addition, comprehensive internal reforms and the requirements of implementing the Association Agreement/ DCFTA signed with the EU increase transformational pressures on the system.

description.narrative: 1.1. No. of essential policy reforms developed and led by MRDI in an inclusive and participatory manner 1.2. MRDI providing effective inter-ministerial coordination and support to the regions and municipalities in developing, implementing and monitoring the development plans; 1.3. Total no. of direct beneficiaries 2.1. No of beneficiaries of the project output (gender disaggregated)1. No of beneficiaries of the project output (gender disaggregated) 2.2 No. of Regional Development Plans and relevant Action Plans developed and adopted in a participatory and inclusive manner in project regions; 2.3. No. of Municipal Development Plans and relevant Action Plans developed and adopted in a participatory and inclusive manner and reflected in the programme budgets 2.4. Adequate participation of women and men in the regional development and municipal planning and implementation ensured

comment.narrative: 1. MRDI is in process of designing policy reforms, but none completed so far; Regional Development Commission established but yet to become fully operational; MRDI to enhance its guidance to regions and municipalities; The upcoming reforms of the LSG system require revisions to the key laws and legal acts; Insufficient policy making and capacities of Parliamentary Committees in relevant subject; MRDI has yet to develop system of donor coordination at policy and thematic levels. 2. No beneficiaries of the project output so far; No RDPs available; No LSG has an up-to date MDP; about 10 LSGs have prior experience in working on MDPs, or an outdated MDP. Hence, no LSG have programme budgets reflecting MDP priorities; Women, generally take less than 20% places in discussions and decision-making (11% in Sakrebulos). 3. GOG decree #1182/2012 establishing the basis for training of MRDI, Governors and LSG civil servants; GOG has allocated no budgetary resources for training LSG officials; No systemic and state coordinated trainings organized for LSGs .

1.1 At least 300 person/days of training organized to improve staff capacities in 11 key areas-identified from functional analyses 1.2 At least 3 key policy areas and resources fully decentralized to local government, including : central competencies staff management and incentivisation local development policy and project development monitoring and accounting for resources spent on participatory local and regional development 1.3 By 2015 at least 4 sectoral and cross-sectoral policy debates and legislative discussions facilitated by the Parliamentary Committee on RPSG; At least 10 draft laws related to the regional and local governance reform/ development initiated/moved to the parliamentary readings by the Parliamentary Committees 1.4 By 2015 the national legislation essentially in line with the European charter of local self-governance more than 30 legal acts related to the regional and local governance reform and development adopted and improved 1.5 By 2015 LSG primary competencies widened; By 2015 municipal budgets (excluding Tbilisi) make at least 12% of consolidated budget
2.1 At least 6 regions and at least 20 municipalities have pro-poor development strategies developed and adopted in a participatory and inclusive manner (with participation of at least 40% of women) and resourced 2.2 At least 3 actions from RDPs and at least 10 actions from MDPs implemented; At least 75% of these actions are gender sensitive 2.3 At least 40,000 inhabitants are benefited from the development projects and improved services; At least 40% of beneficiaries are female 2.4 At least 10 municipalities adopting programme budgets in line with the MDPs 2.5 At least 12% of women are elected in local Sakrebulos (up from 10.5%)

1.1 During 2015, 292 person/days of training were organized covering 154 national officials (52% female). 1.2 Ongoing RLD legal expertise supports alignments of more than 170 sectoral laws with the 2014 LSG Code. A number transfer significant areas of competence to municipalities, such as education, childcare, municipal transportation, parking regulations, domestic animals, waste management (i.e. not just waste collection). These amendments will be submitted as a package for Parliamentary consideration and approval in the Spring 2016 session. 1.3 During 2015, Chair and other members of the PC on RPSG participated in following policy meetings/discussions: (1) four Committee and Plenary debates on Law on Development of High Mountainous Regions; (2) workshop on alignment of sectoral laws with 2014 LSG Law and Code; (3) seminar on principles for MPD preparation; (4) study visit to Austrian mountain regions; 4) Study visit on regional development issues in Czech republic and Poland. 1.4 Direct election of Mayors and Gamgebelis introduced in line with the European Charter through the 2014 LSG code. Besides:(a) Law on Development of High Mountainous Regions adopted on 31 July 2015 for implementation of certain support measures from 1 January 2016.(b) Law on Regional Development and Policy Planning, further specifying roles and responsibilities in the field of regional development of the institutions and stakeholders, including village assemblies, completed inter-Ministerial consultations 1.5( a)In addition to competencies for water supply and melioration; housing homeless people, and care of stray animals, cultural heritage monuments, and other transferred by the 2014 LSG Code, agreement was reached between Ministries on transfers of further significant competencies to municipalities, such as education, childcare, municipal transportation, parking regulations, domestic animals, waste management. These amendments will be submitted for Parliamenta

1.1. The VET colleges in Ambrolauri, Kachreti, Akhaltsikhe, Telavi, Bagdadi and Zugdidi University are conducting updated agricultural vocational programmes providing training to current and future farmers. In 2015 24 farmers/students per college were trained based on specialized programmes. In addition, about 72 farmers benefited from short-term trainings, provided as non-formal training courses at the colleges. Those trainings were implemented based on needs assessment and newly introduced first-in-Georgia modular training programmes designed with the support of the Project. 320 farmers got extension consulting from the local extension services. 1.2. The project supported the development of infrastructure in 5 colleges mainly with specialized equipment for agricultural workshops. 1.3. 5 colleges (Ambrolauri, Kachreti, Akhaltsikhe, Telavi, Bagdadi and Senaki Branch of Zugdidi University) have updated their own strategic plans. The plans contain as well the vision for college-based agriculture extension activities. 2.2. The VET colleges in Ambrolauri, Kachreti, Akhaltsikhe, Telavi, Bagdadi and Zugdidi University (Senaki Branch) are offering updated agricultural programmes. The colleges implemented 8 modular programmes in agriculture starting from 2015. Teachers are undergoing trainings for new program implementation. More than 24 students / college / year are trained. 3.2. Private stakeholders, mostly farmers, are prepared to participate in the newly planned set-up of the VET council and will be nominated for the thematic working group Agriculture, which will serve as organizational format for the dialogue with the private sector and the second thematic working group Work Based Learning. Project actively negotiates the implementation of the Work Based Learning Program with the Georgian Farmers Association (GFA). 3.3. HCFC Phase-Out Management Plan to ensure sustainable and cost-effective phase-out of HCFC according to the schedule of the Montreal Protocol and respective commitments taken by the state.
capital of a political entity
Energy - policy, planning and administration
Georgia freezes HCFC22 consumption by 2013 to meet 10% and 35% reduction targets in 2015 and 2020 according to the Montreal Protocol targets.

comment.narrative: Country obligation to meet agreed targets for HCFC overall consumption reduction
1. Enable Georgia to meet 10% reduction targets of the HCFC22 consumption in 2015 (75.51 tones) according to the Montreal Protocol targets.

1.1 Trainings for technicians, engineers, customs officers conducted. Awareness rising among general population as well as inside targeted groups to improve the safety, efficiency and productivity refrigeration and air-conditioning systems carried out.. 2.1 Standard equipment procured. Two reclaim and recycle centers upgraded. 3.1 Awareness rising among general population as well as inside targeted groups to improve the safety, efficiency and productivity refrigeration and air-conditioning systems carried out.

1. Consumption of HCFC22 reduced and HCFC142b phased out by 2020 and 2016 respectively 2. Improvement of certification system; Streamline ruling legislation, which might include but not limited to introduction of Import Quotas on HCFC22 and equipment containing HCFC22 to avoid boosting of HCFC demand. 3. Trainings for technicians, engineers, customs officers conducted. 4. Awareness rising among general population as well as inside targeted groups to improve the safety, efficiency and productivity refrigeration and air-conditioning systems carried out. 5. Natural refrigerant technologies applied through demonstration projects in the RAC.

Commitments related to ODS consumption reduction are met. Legislation was revised and approved by the Parliament. Capacity of customs officers, technicians of the RAC sector increased through series of training.
Preparation and implementation of the demonstration project in RAC sector, aiming at introduction and support of application of natural refrigerant technologies.

independent political entity

Variety of trainings targeting different beneficiaries; Resource materials prepared to increase the level of awareness and education; Technical support provided to the NOU, so that its' functioning is maintained. Technical support to the RAC sector;

comment.narrative: Government of Georgia requires assistance in enforcement of certification system for RAC technicians as well as further improving the current licensing legislation for ODS consumption and import/export monitoring system, additional capacity building efforts specifically in line with new legislative operations.

Ensure relevant support to the GOG through its' NOU in effective fulfillment of tasks; Provision of technical support to the RAC sector through targeted trainings and provision of necessary equipment. Implementation of awareness rising campaign aiming at general society, as well as targeted activities for youth, children, businesses etc.

Skills and capacity of customs officers for improved control of ODS were increased by providing relevant training sessions on the monitoring of ODS export/import in the country. To assist the Ministry of Environment and Natural Resources Protection of Georgia to introduce certification system for technicians working in the RAC sector relevant training sessions were delivered to technicians working in the refrigerating/air-conditioning sector and on thermal pumps.

comment.narrative: At the seventh year of implementation it is necessary to conduct verification exercise to the project HPMP Stage I project, so that the basis is created for allocation of the next financial tranche.
Conduct full procurement process in order to contract company for implementation of the verification component. Start the process of verification as per the established contract.
Procurement has been successfully finalized and the identified partner company has initiated verification process.
Finalization of the verification process. Review and acceptance of the report by UNDP and the MOENRP of Georgia.
Report is ready and available for submission to the MLF secretariat for review, acceptance and endorsement of subsequent allocation of the next tranche for HPMP project.

Sustainable Management of Pastures in Georgia to Demonstrate Climate Change Mitigation and Adaptation Benefits and Dividends for Local Communities

Rehabilitate 4,064 ha of degraded pastures in Vashlovani Protected Areas, introduce methods for migratory route rehabilitation applied in a 300 ha area and introduce/implement sustainable pasture management practices in the Dedoplistskaro region.
capital of a political entity
Environment - policy, planning and administration

1) Sustainable pasture management plan developed and implemented 2) 300 ha migratory routes rehabilitated; 3) Local farmers knowledge in sustainable land management practices increased and SLM practices applied. 4) Pilot projects established and lessons learned extracted and disseminated. 5) Capacity of Association of sheep-breeders is improved to coordinate the activities. 6) Carbon release and sequestration monitoring established and conducted. 7) Inter-ministerial policy debate on pastures management issues initiated on national level. Key priority actions agreed. 8) Rehabilitation of 4 064 ha of degraded land. 9) Introduction of sustainable land use practices. 10) Monitoring system on climate conditions introduced 11) Introduction of new technologies. 12) Increase in productivity in piloted areas.

1) Starting Implementation of Pasture Management Plan 2) Carbon Stock Inventory 3) Establishment of Veterinary Service for Tush shepherds 4) Preparation of pasture policy recommendations package 5) Exclosure experiment monitoring

1) Carbon Stock Inventory 2016 conducted. The changes between carbon storage in 2013 and 2016 documented. 2) Unified Veterinary Service for Tush shepherds established. Owners of 5000 sheep contracted. 3) Pasture policy gap analysis, best international practice overview and roadmap prepared. 4) Exclosure experiment monitoring 2016 conducted. 5) Implementation of sustainable pasture management plan started with the participation of all stakeholders.

comment.narrative: 13 km to Jamili PA Turkey

After the transfer of landforest to the Machakhela National Park administration from the Forestry Agency of Achara Autonomous Republic in Autumn 2014 the territory is being managed as the protected area and thus the distance between the MtiralaKintrishi PA complex and the nearest forest habitat PA ie Machakhela NP is less than 6km The national boundary of Georgia and Turkey forms the southern boundary of the Machakhela NP The Jamilil Biosphere Reserve lies also along the border and thus the 3rd zone Transition zone is contiguous with Machakhela NP The Machakhela National Park admisnitration has accepted the legal ownershipmanagement of the for

PA official gazettement completed The Government of Georgia undertook efforts at the project development stage to legally establish the Machakhela NP This was agreed by Parliament in April 2012 Detailed boundary demarcation is currently in progress with the support of the project NP Administration has been established and equipped by the Agency of Protected Areas of Georgia Project has supported initial training of NP Administration staff awareness raising within local communities and establishment of the NP administration local authorities and project coordination group as well as refurbishment of NP temporary office within the Machakhela valley

description.narrative: Level of involvement of communities in the management and governance of the NP

comment.narrative: NA

PublicCivil SocietyCommunity PA Planning and Management Governance Board established with proper representation and involvement of local communities in the planning and management of the Machakhela NP by year 2

The Project Coordination Group established and operating that includes local government and community representatives The primary role of this group is to ensure coordination and information sharing during the next 2 years of intense activities to establish the functional capacity of the NP ie boundary and zoning NP Administration training infrastructure and equipment management plan development etc Its secondary important role includes the creation of a mechanism by which the NP and local stakeholders can constructively interact A study of existing and potential mechanisms for maximising practical and meaningful interaction and collaboration between communities living within the borderline of the NP or support zone and the protected area is to be commissioned in the 2nd half of 2015 The study will guide the project on most viable and feasible structures and mechanisms for ensuring community engagement and role in NP management that will be incorporated into the management planning process in 2016

description.narrative: Machakhela NP boundaries and zonation decided and participatory management plan in existence

comment.narrative: Boundaries only provisionally demarcated and zonation not carried out

Clearly defined and consensually agreed boundaries and zones by yr 2
Consensually agreed Management plan exists by yr 3

The project is well on track to meet the target expected date September 2015 A contract to undertake the detailed demarcation and land classification of the NP was selected in April 2015 by the project in agreement with APA The PA boundary demarcation is ongoing including the collection and inputting all existing cartographic land and field surveys data into GIS The contractor closely liaises and informs local government and communities on the progress during implementation of this task This activity is expected to be completed in September 2015 Additionally a contractor has been selected to undertake a detailed resource inventory of the NP and surrounding area baseline studies of biodiversity traditional use cultural heritage etc which will form the baseline for monitoring development of a zoning plan as well as the initial NP management plan scheduled for 2016 The contractor should start its work in August 2015 and complete by February 2016

Both the Agency for Protected Areas and the local municipality have already committed significant resources to the establishment of the NP This includes baseline inputs such as staff basic as well as additional equipment additional used vehicle from APA and as agreed during PPG stage the refurbishment of 4km of the Machakhela valley road by the municipality has been completed during 20142015 project cost around 404000 US

description.narrative: Provision of Equipment and Infrastructure for the Bagratashen-Sadakhlo Border Crossing Point between Armenia and Georgia and enhancement of their capacities
The overall objective of the project is the introduction of European standards of integrated border management at the Bagratashen-Sadakhlo Border Crossing Point on the Armenia-Georgia border.
Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness

1.a.New Border Management Strategy of Georgia drafted 1.b.Increase in detection of cross-border crime cases relevant to introduction of IBM
2. Information exchange intensified among agencies; Standard Operating Procedures developed for all land Border Crossing Points; Public awareness on border crossing procedures raised.
3. Agreement on border delegates between Georgia and Armenia enforced and operational.
4. a. at least 50 senior and operational staff actively participating at the national and bilateral workshops. 4.b. Positive feedback of staff on professional skills development training. 4. c.X-Ray scanner delivered, installed and operational at Sadakhlo BCP.

comment.narrative: 1. Strategic IBM documents such as Border Management Strategy and Action Plan are in place but need to be updated. 2. Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs) at Sadakhlo are in place for Patrol Police, but joint SOPs with the Revenue Service need to be developed. 3.International agreement on border delegates between Georgia and Armenia should be endorsed along with additional protocols. 4. Lack of adequate equipment and training of senior and operational staff of border operating agencies.

1.Public Awareness on IBM raised 2. Georgia-Armenia bilateral agreements, national secondary level legislation & regulations improved. 3. Sadakhlo BCP is equipped with modern devices to facilitate effective operation of border management agencies and smooth crossing of border for the public.

1. E-book on border legislation prepared and displayed at project website. Leaflets distributed at Border Crossing Points 2 a. Protocol on exchange of preliminary customs information between the two countries elaborated. 2 b. Joint SOPs for customs and patrol police drafted for Sadakhlo BCP as well as Batumi and Kutaisi airports. 3. X-ray scanner for trucks, automatic number plate recognition systems, borescope cameras, incinerators and passport readers procured and in use at Sadakhlo BCP.

description.narrative: Assistance to Georgia in preparation of its first Biennial Update Report (BUR) for the fulfillment of the obligations under the UNFCCC
Assistance to Georgia in preparation of its first Biennial Update Report (BUR) for the fulfillment of the obligations under the UNFCCC.
independent political entity
Biennial Update Report (BUR) completed and submitted to UNFCCC (Y/N). GHG emissions inventory report for 2010-2011 is updated and for 2012-2013 is completed.

comment.narrative: Georgia pledged to submit its first Biennial Update Report (BUR) to the UNFCCC by 2016; National Circumstance Chapter of SNC covers situation until 2012; Georgias GHG inventory submitted to the UNFCCC covers years until 2012; Mitigation strategy is currently being prepared under the TNC; UNEP TNA was completed in September 2012. Georgias First Biennial Update Report will build on the findings and recommendations of Third National Communication, as well as the outcomes of the ongoing complementary projects in the country, and will be submitted to the UNFCCC in 2016.

description.narrative: The overall objective of the action is to improve operational capacities of the border agencies of Azerbaijan and Georgia by organizing and carrying out coordinated operations at land border.

The overall objective of the project is to improve operational capacities of the border agencies of Azerbaijan and Georgia by ensuring coordinated operations at land border with eventual positive impact on overall security in the region and whole Europe.
independent political entity
Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness

1.Intergovernmental Agreement on border delegates between Georgia and Azerbaijan enforced and operationalised.
2 a. EU Best Practices of border guarding and border surveillance presented to senior operational staff 2.b. Coordinated patrolling by Georgian and Azeri border guards conducted on a regular basis. 2.c. At least 50 senior and operational staff actively participating at the national and bilateral thematic workshops 2.d.Positive feedback of staff on professional skills development training 2.e. Training programs for the border guard agencies of two countries are in place and use
3. New Sector offices built and provided to the project area sectors;Specialised equipment is installed and operational; Border staff trained in the use and maintenance of the new equipment.

comment.narrative: Border Cooperation agreement between Georgia and Azerbaijan is in place. However, the international agreement on border delegates between two countries should be endorsed and additional protocols on cooperation updated. There is also a problem of poor infrastructure on Georgian side of the border, lack of adequate equipment as well as lack of coordinated patrolling along the land border .

1.Basic Training Program for Border Guards updated and endorsed and 15 senior officials of border operating agencies have been trained. 2. List of needed subjects for training identified and prepared 3. More than 20 border officials trained on land border surveillance so far. 4. Construction of two sector office buildings commenced

1. Bilateral agreement on Activities of Border Representatives/Border Commissars between Azerbaijan and Georgian Governments was drafted. Relevant national and bilateral workshops were conducted. 2. The training pro-gramme was elaborated and respective trainers were identified. 28 trainers were trained in the area of Stress and Con-flict management and Second Line Document Inspection. 3. 124 senior and oper-ational staff partici-pated at trainings. 4. Vehicles for Border Police of MIA of Georgia were purchased

For 2016 CCCD project in Georgia targeted to accomplish the tasks contributing to the identification of needs and definition of scope for the development of environmental information/knowledge management system. To that end the consequent activities planned in each quarter clarified the expectations of the stakeholders over the system and capacities to be developed. In particular in the first quarter: Existing stakeholders involved in the implementation of UNCBD, UNCCD, UNFCC, and their respective roles and responsibilities, including legal mandates as well as institutional overlaps and/or gaps were identified and assessed; Target agencies with responsibilities to manage environmental information were identified and design for the climate change, biodiversity and land related data and information exchange was proposed and agreed. The second quarter was dedicated to the development of and consultations on the concept for the web-based environmental information/knowledge management system; identification of key issues on systemic, institutional and individual levels for the monitoring of trends related to climate change, biodiversity and land and development of recommendations for filling the gaps. The third and fourths quarters were mainly concentrated on identification of and agreeing on datasets and respective indicators to be the part of the web-based system, identification of missing responsibilities for generation of data and information relevant for the monitoring of trends in the climate change, biodiversity and land; investigation of compliance of national legislation with provisions on monitoring obligations under the Rio Conventions and the development of the design of web-based environmental information/knowledge management system; In addition in the fourth quarter relevant data and information kept/produced at non-governmental/academic and private sectors were assessed and the possibilities for the inclusion of the data into the web-based syst

Developed web-based environmental information/knowledge management system for data/information collection, sharing and monitoring related to climate change, biodiversity and land Proposed legal framework for the monitoring and implementation of Rio Conventions Proposed inter-ministerial cooperation mechanisms and procedures

comment.narrative: Requirements for the ratification of Minamata convention are not determined in Legislation and regulatory framework ; Capacity needs in regard to the implementation of Convention provisions are nit identified; Low awareness level on the environmental and health impacts of Mercury in the country; Low or no national capacities for undertaking Mercury inventories; National inventory has never been conducted and the Mercury profile does not exist;

Assessment of legislation, policy and regulatory frameworks with the purpose to identify gaps for meeting the requirements of the Convention; Assessment of Institutional capacity and needs to determine gaps, capacity needs and barriers (legal and functional) to meet the requirements of the Convention; Preparation of draft package of recommendations (conceptual, new legislation/legal clauses and amendments and supplements to the existing legislation as appropriate) in all relevant areas of the Minamata Convention; Preparation of Roadmap for ratification and implementation of Minamata obligations; timing of national steps for adoption of necessary legislation/supplements to the existing legislation;Review and analysis of the situation with regard to public awareness on Mercury related health and environmental risks;Preparation of mercury Communication Strategy and Action Plan; Awareness rising activities carried out targeting different segments of audience

1. Strengthen National capacities for undertaking mercury inventories 2. Conduct National inventory and prepare the Mercury Profile 3. Prepare and publish National Mercury Initial Assessment Report (Minamata Initial Assessment)

With the purpose to develop Minamata Initial Assessment report the following reports and materials were prepared: - Report on public health aspects of mercury exposure. - Report on the assessment of potential gender dimensions related to the management of mercury. - Mercury inventory maps; - With the purpose to facilitate communication and information sharing on Minamata Convention with stakeholders, the texts of the Convention was translated into Georgian -National Mercury Initial Assessment Report (Minamata Initial Assessment) prepared and published.

description.narrative: Human Rights for All Support to the Implementation and Monitoring of the National Human Rights Strategy and Action Plan

Overall objective of the Joint Programme (JP) is to enhance capacities of government institutions and Parliamentary Committees on Rights and Civil Integration and Legal Issues and improve mechanisms for better protection of human rights in Georgia.
independent political entity
Human rights affairs

comment.narrative: Progress Report for 2014-2015 NHRSAP is developed and submitted to the Parliament Actions Plan for 2016-2017 Prepared and Approved NHRS and its action plans implementation progresses; Visibility on Human Rights for general public is improved the staff of Public Service Development Agency have better capacity to protect personal data Awareness of PDPI office is improved Amendments to the Regulation of the Parliament are adopted to promote the oversight role of the parliament over human rights issues, with special emphasis on implementation of PDO and UN Human Rights Mechanisms recommendations strengthened to a significant extent and institutionalized in legal framework

The progress report was submitted to the parliament in Spring 2016 The Action Plan approved by the government on 6 June 2016 The implementation is in progress. 2016 implementation due in March 2017. The Project supported awareness raising activities on human rights, especially on rights of PwDs and personal data protection. The Survey conducted by the Project revealed that awareness on HRs improved significantly since 2012. More than 200 PSDA staff members trained on PDP standards. Together with PDPI the Project implemented a number of awareness activities, including PDP weekends, awareness campaign at high education universities and through social media. The amendments were adopted in June 2016 strengthening the oversight of the parliament on implementation of PDO recommendations.

Baseline 2.2.1/ Considering that greater majority of municipalities of Georgia currently are not covered by vocational education institutions, National Strategy of Vocational Education development envisages introduction of vocational education programs in secondary schools. Currently there are no secondary schools in Georgia which conduct vocational education programs.

Baseline 3/ Life-Long-Learning (LLL) system in VET is not developed in Georgia.

comment.narrative: Baseline 1: Current extension model needs improvement and adjustment to newly emerging needs in terms of products diversification, optimization of existing ones, extension monitoring and quality control and management. Baseline 2: Production of farm holdings is of low productivity and low income Baseline 3: MoA needs further capacity development in evidence-based policy planning, application of scientific research outcomes in farming ; low income holdings and ineffective production chains

1.1 Practical Extension Service Package for strategic crops in Ajara and Extension Service Package for Fish Farming developed and started to provide to farmers. 1.2 AS Centre extension staff were retrained in walnuts and hazelnuts modern farming 1.3 Special software is used for M&E of Extension Services provided by ASC 1.5 All ASC branches were equipped with modern optical microscopes which will help to extension workers to identify plants diseases on early stage; The following guide book was issued and distributed: Identification and control of Major Diseases of Vegetables and Melons in Georgia 1.6 ASC and MoA Ajara provided extension services to more than 2.809 farms 2.1 The following production chains was identified and analyzed: Citrus; Berry and hazelnuts farming. 2.4 12 cooperatives were supported through grant assistant; all of them are managed in a successful and sustainable manner 2.3 73 participants (o/w 53 women) attended trainings in specifications of Agriculture Accounting and expenditure management; 15 Agricultural cooperatives received service in agriculture accounting provided by BDS

description.narrative: Support to Public Administration reform/ GRF 2/UK -Together with partners, UNDP assists the Government of Georgia in steering and successful implementation of the Public Administration Reform (PAR).
independent political entity

comment.narrative: - Change Management Plan and respective Communication Plan is developed - A scoping mission to support the Administration of Government in establishing unified performance tracking and monitoring system was conducted by an international expert on M&E - A thorough analysis of available performance appraisal systems was conducted with six partner ministries with active involvement of local HR experts and respective performance appraisal models best-suited for individual ministries were selected. - Awareness of public servants on new Law on Civil Service is enhanced through provision of trainings for 350 servants complemented with additional awareness raising measures - A baseline study of the current service delivery practices in Georgia was conducted and relevant report produced. - Four research and five CSO grants focusing on three key areas of PAR: policy development, civil service reform and public service delivery were selected and funded as part of the first and second cycles of the research and CSO grants competition.

description.narrative: ENHANCING ACCESS TO JUSTICE AND DEVELOPMEMT OF A CHILD-FRIENDLY JUSTICE SYSTEM IN GEORGIA

title.narrative: UN JP on Access to Justice

description.narrative: Overall objective of the project is to enhance capacities of government institutions to promote access to justice for all and qualitative, coherent and child-friendly justice system for children in Georgia.
independent political entity
Human rights affairs

comment.narrative: he access to justice is guaranteed by the legislation however practical implementation faces challenges due to weakness of main players in the field

1) Better access to justice is guaranteed for vulnerable through efficient and effective legal aid system; - Case Bank upgraded for civil and administrative cases; - 2-year Training plan for LAS lawyers is developed - Refurbishment of LAS head office launched - Draft Regulation of LAS developed and submitted to LAS board - Trainings on civil, administrative and criminal law for LAS lawyers in line with training plan conducted (at least 20 trainings)
2) Legal Profession is independent and able contribute to high quality protection of interests of citizens; - 2016-2017 AP of Georgian Bar Association developed - capacity of GBA lawyers enhanced through targeted trainings - New modules and trainers are available for GBA training centre for CLE - International Cooperation of GBA is enhanced 3) ADRs is broadly applied, including in the regions - Draft Law on Mediation is submitted to the Ministry of Justice - Knowledge building on mediation through legal profession and general public - International Conference on Mediation conducted - Knowledge building on Arbitration - Arbitration Glossary prepared and published - 3rd Conference "GIAC arbitration days" conducted

1) Better access to justice is guaranteed for vulnerable through efficient and effective legal aid system; LAS new regulation approved Electronic case-management programme for registry lawyers launched LAS head office refurbished Recommendations for the provision free legal aid in plea bargaining cases drafted. Quality monitoring standards for civil/administrative cases drafted Targeted trainings identified by training needs assessment survey conducted A plan for the adaptation of LAS offices for PWDs adopted. Recommendations for the creation of effective Legal Referral System drafted; Electronic Platform for Free Legal Aid Providers created. Based on survey results awareness raising strategy prepared. Renewed LAS webpage launched Recommendations for the implementation of LAS distant service system as well as relevant regulations drafted. 2) Legal Profession is independent and able contribute to high quality protection of interests of citizens; GBA internal regulations be revised in accordance with legislative changes; HR strategy drafted, Job descriptions revised GBA Annual Conference held Trainings on targeted areas based on training needs assessment conducted Recommendations for the increase of financial sustainability of GBA produced Donor coordination meeting on GBA conducted. Activities envisaged by GBA 2017-2018 Action Plan supported. 3) ADRs is broadly applied, including in the regions Law on Mediation Adopted. The Code of Ethics for Mediators adopted. At least 15 Judges trained in referral skills to mediation in cooperation with the HSoJ. At least 15 Judges trained in arbitration. At least 240 lawyers (out of which up to 200 lawyers from regions including lawyers of LAS trained in basics of mediation. Research identifying the possible reasons for slow development of arbitration as method of dispute resolution conducted. Strategic Development Plan for Georgian Arbitrators Association adopted. A

title.narrative: Study and Research on Election Media Coverage for 2017

description.narrative: Conducting of media monitoring for 2017 Local Self Government Elections to assess media performance during elections

title.narrative: Study and Research on Election Media Coverage for 2017
Study and Research on Election Media Coverage for 2017

description.narrative: Study and Research on Election Media Coverage for the 2017 Local Government Elections in Georgia-Media Monitoring for Local Elections
independent political entity
Other General Services - support to civil society

Election media reporting improved in line with election standards and independence of media enhanced in comparison to previous years; - Quantitative indicators revealed as a result of the MM reflecting the dynamics in terms of balanced and unbiased coverage - Observing the interest and public attitude towards MM through collecting the data including through the already existing website www.mediamonitor.ge - The quality of the products provided by the CSOs

comment.narrative: The baseline actions build upon the activities implemented within the 2016 media monitoring cycle, as well as other monitoring initiatives as mentioned above. More specifically: The media monitoring skills and methods provided to CSOs within the previous project will be applied and utilized more intensively in the proposed action. The network of relations with mass media outlets (TV, internet, print and radio), media associations, international and local civil society organizations (CSOs), and active public groups developed within the previous project will be further enhanced. Findings of the proposed action will be checked against those from the previous round of monitoring and a new set of recommendations will be developed. Media rating research implemented within the previous projects will serve as a baseline for new inquiries in the media landscape assessments. Increased risk of political pressure on local journalists and media outlets in the run up to local government elections of 2017. The allegations that the practices of pressure over the media have increased. The polarization seems to be rising. Specific methodology and criteria exist to analyse news, political and elections related talk shows. However, they are not in use as the MM is not ongoing.

-Advanced MM capacities in place with MM results available for structured debates for 2017 Local Self-Governance Elections -Key media sources monitored prior-, during and immediately after 2017 Local Self-Government Elections - The quantitative and qualitative data reflecting the performance of Georgian media in particular during 2017 Local Self Government Elections and showing the latest state of media in general.
